title: Accounting for the Charity Sector
headline: Learn how to manage accounts and finances for charity and not-for-profit organisations with this free online course.
description: The charity sector is a growing segment of economic activities that provides exciting career opportunities for accounting professionals. But accounting for charities is uniquely different from conventional accounting. We understand the intricacies involved and thus have come up with this course, ‘Accounting for the Charity Sector’. It will help you master all the modern principles and practices of charity accounting.
courseDescription:
Are you a budding professional who wants to sharpen your skills and choose a specialised accounting function? Or are you a seasoned accounting professional who cannot seem to grab exciting career opportunities in the charity or not-for-profit domain? Unfortunately, most studies in accounting usually cater to conventional accounting. This course bridges the gap between the two and will teach you how to handle the accounting work for your organisation's corporate social responsibility (CSR) department. It provides an in-depth and detailed study of all the modern types, functions, practices and accounting principles in the charity sector.

We understand that accounting never comes easy. Therefore, we have divided this course into clear-cut but specific modules and topics to help you understand and master all the relevant features, functions and practices of charity accounting. We begin by defining the concept and principles of charity accounting. Next, our tutorials will slowly and steadily walk you through the most relevant and modern accounting tools, techniques and approaches for effective account management in the charity sector. Finally, we will test your knowledge through engaging assessment questions to make sure you understand the subject matter. By the end of this course, you will be better prepared and confident enough to handle accounting and finance-related work in the charity and not-for-profit sectors.

The charity sector is multiplying. As a result, it has created a high demand for qualified and eligible charity accounting and financial professionals. 'Accounting for the Charity Sector' is an ideal course that matches the needs and demands of this sector. We have created it for accountants, auditors, managers and consultants who aim to switch or advance their careers in this demanding specialised sector. The contents demonstrate the practical realities and functions and equip you with the knowledge, skills and expertise to confidently work and grow in this vocation. So join the course today and get ready to move into this highly in-demand field of being an accountant or financial professional in the charity or not-for-profit sector.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The main purpose of charities is the relief from poverty, the advancement of education, the advancement of religion, and other purposes considered beneficial to the community.
    • Charities can be classified as either grant-making or fundraising although some fundraising charities frequently also engage in grant-making activities.
    • The charity accounting process includes summarizing, analyzing, and reporting the financial transaction to the trustees, regulators, and tax collection entities.
    • The SORP explains how charities should present and disclose their activities and funds in their accounts, as well as how they should regulate their specific activities and transactions.
    • When selecting accounting policies for the treatment of specific items, transactions or events in the accounts, charities must refer to FRS 102 and the regulations in the SORP.
    • The receipts and payments account simply summarize all money received and paid out by the charity with a detailed statement of assets and liabilities in the financial year.Accruals accounts present a clearer picture of the charity’s finances showing income and expenditure and adjusting debtors, creditors and accruals during the year.
    • The primary purpose of the trustee's annual report is to ensure that the charity is publicly accountable to its stakeholders for the stewardship and management of the funds it holds on trust.
    • A balance sheet is a statement giving an overview of a charity’s assets and liabilities.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define the statement of financial activities (SOFA).
    • Describe in detail SOFA structure and headings.
    • Recognize income source and expenditure and the general rules related to them.
    • Explain the statement of cash flow, its structure, methods, and template.
    • Summarize required taxation and tax relief for charities and applicable scrutiny for charity accounts.
    • Discuss how to manage post- Covid situations and issues arising for charities.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The statement of financial activities (SOFA) is a single accounting statement that includes all income, gains, expenses, and losses recognized during the reporting period.
    • All of the charity's income and expenditure, transfers, and other recognized gains and losses must be analyzed among the classes of funds.
    • Income is an in streaming of resources that increase the charity’s assets or decrease its liabilities.
    • Charitable expenditure is the expenses that charity has obtained solely for charitable purposes, including items such as charitable grants and administrative expenses.
    • The statements of cash flow demonstrate how a charity uses the cash generated by its activities, as well as changes in cash and cash equivalent held by the charity.
    • An audit is the most comprehensive investigation of financial statements, and the auditor looks for evidence that will allow the accounts to be described as ‘true and fair’.
    • The narrative provided in the trustee’s annual report regarding Covid 19 should be proportionate to the risks faced by the charity.
    • Charities should explain any financial uncertainties regarding the charity’s financial sustainability and consideration of going concern, including the steps being taken to address these uncertainties.
    • Unless the legal duty to report the outcome of external scrutiny is relaxed by the government in times of a national emergency, the auditor or examiner must still report matters of material significance.
